title: Cooper Union protestors peacefully vacate president's office after 65 day occupation
content:
Culture -

The New York university famous for its top-notch arts and engineering programs - and for being free - has fallen on hard times.

To protest a new tuition plan, a group of about 30 students staged a planned occupation of Cooper Union President Jamshed Bharucha's office when it opened. By midday on their first day, the group had grown to about 60 and black banners had been unfurled from the windows.

The students occupying the president's office peacefully vacated July 12 in exchange for an invitation to join school officials in an effort to find a solution to the school's financial problems. The school will also add a student representative to its board of trustees, and will not penalize protestors for their actions.

The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art announced on Apr. 23 that it would begin charging undergrad tuition in fall 2014 for the first time in its 154 years. Students the school determines can afford it, will pay about $20,000; others will pay based on a sliding scale.

Related Storyline On Circa

With an acceptance rate of 8%, Cooper Union is one of the most competitive colleges in the country. It is running an annual deficit of $12 million due to rising expenses, faltering fund-raising drives, and $10 million-a-year payments on $175 million the school borrowed largely to invest in stocks.

"Under the new policy, the Cooper Union will continue to adhere to the vision of Peter Cooper, who founded the institution specifically to provide a quality education to those who might not otherwise be able to afford it." Mark Epstein, chairman of the Cooper Union board

Cooper Union announced tuition for graduate students in 2012, but that didn't solve the problem. Students protested the plan vigorously, but Cooper Union decided to charge undergrads after hiring a consulting firm to gauge the impact.
